content: The 9/11 Commission found that al Qaeda terrorists exploited weaknesses in aviation security, including a focus on potential bombers, lax checkpoint screening, lack of in-flight security measures, compliance with hijackers, and a failure of imagination among senior officials. The 9/11 Commission identified a failure of imagination among senior officials in recognizing the threat of suicide hijackings by al Qaeda. Despite concerns about hijackings, no specific actions were taken to defend against this threat before September 11, 2001. The likelihood of a suicide hijacking scenario was underestimated, leading to a lack of preparedness in the aviation security system. The 9/11 Commission found that before September 11, 2001, there was a lack of specific actions taken to defend against potential hijacking scenarios, particularly suicide hijackings. After 9/11, Congress quickly passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act to address security weaknesses. After the 9/11 attacks, Congress passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) to address aviation security weaknesses. ATSA established the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security in all transportation modes, focusing on aviation. Key measures included federal security screeners at airports, explosive detection screening for checked bags, air marshals on high-risk flights, and reinforced cockpit doors.
